I returned that one, because the bezel around the screen, invaded the screen to much to make the device prove useful when reading magazines, and for viewing some webpages.Also, I have owned pretty much every tablet made including, the ipad 1 & 2, Samsung Galaxy Tab (orginial), Kindle Fire HD 7", Kindle Paperwhite, Microsoft Surface Pro, and most recently the Dell Venue Pro 8.I feel qualified to speak to the usability of this tablet in comparison to the others and in its own right. What I will not do in my review is review the technical aspects of the HDX, as you can read them on the product page.1. First Impressions:This device is solidly built, and it light as a feather. It is really a shame to put a case on this device as anything that makes this baby heavier is a shame. For the women out there that may be wondering, if you threw this in your handbag, your arm would not fall off, provided you have it stowed in a sleeve case or very light weight case. The speakers are placed at the top of the device and have a good output of sound at low and high volume. If you are using the device flat on a table it can muffle the sounds a bit.2. Screen:The screen is perfect. No blue haze, or abnoramalities whatsoever. The brightness of the screen is wonderful, and while I have not used the device outside, I have used it sitting near a window with the sun streaming in and I had no problems seeing the screen.3. Ecosystem (OS)It should not be a surprise to anyone that this device points to Amazon's ecosystem. People that knock this tablet for this seem to be off base. If you want a google tablet with no restictions, then buy a Nexus or some other type of tablet. Amazon is not going to build a table that points to another company ecosystem, anymore than Apple would allow you to interact with Google directly. Lowering the rating of the HDX for this reason is unwarranted.Using the Kindle OS is simple, and the onscreen hints help for first time users. If you are coming from a previous generation Kindle you should be able to navigate without much trouble with a few small differences. I also use Amazon's Cloud service for photos and docs, and you probably should also. Installing the Cloud Photo app on your cell phone will allow any picture you take to upload to the cloud and once you register your HDX, they will automatically populate. Such an awesome and thoughtful feature. The Cloud Doc feature works the same, install on your PC or Mac and any document you drag into the doc folder will automatically show up on your HDX4. Music Player:To my surprise, the HDX will show the lyrics to certain songs that have the Xray enabled. This is an awesome feature if you are someone that likes to know the words to songs, or if you are like me, a singer, and need to actually KNOW the lyrics to some songs. If you also have songs in Amazon's Cloud Music Player these will automatically populate on your Kindle when you register is, and if the lyrics are available they automatically show. You can also place your music directly on your Kindle via usb as well from your PC or MAC if you want.5. Kindle Book ReaderI read entire book on my HDX just to make sure that I did not have eye strain or any other issues before deciding to rate this tablet. Amazon for me has always been about books first and of course my HDX excels here as well. I read well into the night and all the next day with no eye fatigue, or issues.6. Video/Prime SubscriptionOk, people here are getting upset about the prime subscription. For the $79 bucks a year you get free 2 day shipping on most anything in the Amazon market place and a thousands of free movies, of which some are downloadable, 1 free book you can borrow each month, and now a free book that is new to the Kindle store to preview. That's a lot of stuff to consider, and yes there are improvements to be made, such as choosing a movie from the Prime Movies to Download category showed movies that I could not download along side the downloadable ones (so why the category?) but overall, its not a deal breaker. You have a month to decide either way.The videos are beautiful, with wonderful color and sound. Not much to say here. This was another expected point.7. ProductivityI wanted to see if the tablet could really function as quasi laptop for when I was out of the office and still needed to stay in touch with work. I added my Microsoft Exchange Account (along with my personal email accounts) and was surprised to see that my work email was able to sync easily along with my Exchange Calendar. All my contacts were added to the HDX as well. The true test came when I needed to open a spreadsheet emailed to me, which I was able to do. The HDX comes with a program that allows you to view office documents, to edit requires you to purchase the full version. I own my own business, so being out of the loop is never really an option, and I am always looking for devices to allow me some acces to work without carrying 3 or 4 different devices.8. PrintingI was able to print to my HP Laserjet printer, the HDX required me to download a HP Printer App, which allowed me to print an email just fine. You are supposed to be able to print emails and docs. I would like to be able to print from the Silk Browser as well, but I'm not sure that this device allows that. Maybe I'm wrong. Somebody please correct me if I am.9. Mayday Button:This may seem gimmicky, until you actually need help, which I did. I purchased another HDX for my husband, and while setting up his, all the books and music and newsstand items synced, but not the apps. Odd to say the least! I pushed the Mayday Button and within seconds I was connected to a nice lady who tried to help me, but was unable to fix my problem. She transfered me to another woman, who I could not see as she was with Kindle Second Level Support, but who I was able to speak to online. She needed to call me back becuause I had to reset the HDX, which she did right away, and helped me solve my issue. Which by the way was to deregister and then re-register the device and everything was able to sync perfectly.10. Magazine Reading:As I stated earlier reading a magazine on the 7" HDX is just too small to see the pictures and text completely. The 8.9" solves that problem, opening up a whole new world for me. I subscribe to several boating magazines, where there are a lot of pictures of beautiful boats that I want to see. Also, utilizing the 'reading view' allows you to pull the article you are reading into one cohesive reading screen. Great!11. BrowsingSilk is fast and easy to use. Not sure why people do not like it. Not much to say here.12. BluetoothI was able to pair the HDX to a Bose Speaker easily and an external keyboard within seconds. Again, not much to say here, bluetooth works as expected.In conclusion, I hoped I have answered any questions you may have from the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" I cannot really speak to gaming, as I do not use any gaming apps, but take it from somebody that loves trying out new tablet, this one is definately one I'd recommend to someone that loves to read, watch movies, read a few emails, and listen to their favorite music. This a consumption device, and all roads lead you to being able to read, watch, listen or browse easily and quickly.**Update 12/21/2013**I thought I'd update you on how my and my husband's experience has been with the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9.My husband has an Ipad2 which he uses daily. I have noticed that he uses the Kindle Fire a lot more everyday. I asked him about his experience and he told me that the Kindle Fire is much lighter and the screen resolution is better. The only thing that stops him for using it fully, it that he has some apps he paid for on the Ipad that he does not want to pay for again. He is a bit of a technophobe, and he has also found that navigating the Kindle is pretty easy.We also purchased the device with special offers and he really likes it. He likes getting the special deals on the lock screen, and even the recommendations from the Carousel.He is a big Netflix, Slingbox, HBOGO user, and he finds that the Kindle Fire handles all of these apps well.My experience is really surprising for me, as I find myself using my Kindle Fire HDX for work a lot more. I can easily look up information on our company website when I am away from my office, and even respond to emails easily. I am having a bit a trouble transferring documents to my Kindle via usb for some reason. PDFs and word docs transfer easily, but for some reason excel files will not. Not sure why I keep getting an error. Beware though, it does take a few minutes for docs transferred via usb to show up on the Kindle for some reason.Working with the docs with the Office Suite App is pretty easy too!Revision 1/4/2014There seems to be some problem with my Fire HDX hanging a lot. I am getting a message saying that I do not have a wireless connection, when clearly I have full bars. I have made sure there is no issue with my WI-FI - none of my other devices are losing a signal. The only fix is to disconnect from the network and reconnect and then I can continue with what I was doing.I also have had an issue playing videos. Both on Prime, and on the A&E; App. At first I thought it was the app, so I closed it an reopened, still was unable to play videos. Next I tried to watch a Amazon video and was unable to even pull up the first screen that pops up when you press video. I had to turn my Fire on and off before I was able to play any videos. I do not that sometimes these devices need to be turned off and on to 'clear' or reset them, but with these two issues, I'm getting a little concerned. The WI-FI issue is starting to be a hourly occurance. I am going to have to press Mayday to find out what is going on. I will have to lower my review by one star. This whole device is dependent on the wireless connection. If that does not work well, then it's just a nice looking paperweight.

Reviews.Title: Let's take a look....
Reviews.Author: ND Mike "rabid1"
Reviews.Content: First things first. I have been one of the most outspoken people against Kindle tablets. The lack of hardware options and the proprietary interface always were a big minus to me. That is why writing this review is painful in soooo many ways.As a big supporter and developer for the lesser brand and generic tablets I have owned around 50 tablets in the last 3 years. I always look at hardware potential first, OS functionality second because that can be fixed. That is also why I decided to check out the Fire HDX 8.9. The hardware specs made it difficult to believe it can't deliver. It does indeed deliver.While benchmarks can often be misleading in real world application but they still give a good performance comparison and an idea of what to expect. In Quadrant it hits with a blazing 19,546 and in Antutu it jumps in at 31,765. To put this into perspective the Galaxy Note * get's about 18,000 in Antutu.The tablet is thin and light to the point of thinking I got an empty shell, but it still manages to feel solid. I have an Afunta 8 inch that while a little heavier still feels like it is going to break in your hands. As thin as the HDX is there is no flex to the case.When I booted the HDX the display is obviously the first thing I noticed. (OK the boot speed surprised me first) It is really crisp and bright and the colors are crisp. Even when set at the lowest brightness movies are still entirely watchable. The touchscreen itself is very responsive, a little sensitive so it took a a bit of getting used to. But having big fingers isn't the tablet fault.Both the N and A wifi are strong and solid. The 5GHZ connection is the best of the 3 tablets I have that use it. The 32GB HP Touchpad is the closest. I can hold -55dbm all the way out to the curb. With Netflix set to the highest quality it needs no refresh time when the movie starts.The speaker quality is easily the best I have experienced. Not just volume but actual sound quality.The rear camera with flash always sounds great. I have several tablets with this feature and up until I bought the Sero 7 Pro it has always been short of useless. The HDX exceeds the 7 Pro. The pictures taken with flash off the HDX look like they came off a camera, not a tablet with a camera on it.As for the things the HDX is missing. HDMI out, MicroSD, I can't knock off points for thing that you should know about before you buy. Lack of research on the part of the buyer isn't the manufacturers fault. Just like knocking a tablet for not having Google Play when it isn't a Google certified device.  You don't buy a chain saw to hammer nails do you?As for apps it is simple enough to side load apps onto the HDX.I really was planning on writing a scathing review thus justifying my dislike for proprietary tablets. But as a pure tablet the Kindle Fire HDX is amazing. There are tablets within the price point that may have more features, but none can do what the HDX does as well as the HDX. That goes for much more expensive tablets as well. Time will tell if there will be a lot of independent development on the HDX but I would guess the hardware will draw developers like candy draws a fat kid.

Reviews.Title: one more
Reviews.Author: Gene
Reviews.Content: I have been buying kindles since the 1st generation, so I will leave the very wordy reviews to others and simply tell you, this is the fastest smoothest kindle so far. I am surprised how much faster and  user friendly this HEX is, BUT IT KEEPS AUTO CORECTING HEX $$_#)(5#4#. Guess I will be turning that off. But this is the one to buy. Trust me I wouldn't lie to you.  HDX- THERE I TURNED AUTO CORECT OFF:)I have been using my 8.9hdx for a few weeks now and I must say I am more impressed than ever, I almost never use my i-pad ANYMORE, This HDX is a quantum leap from the HD.

Reviews.Title: Worth the upgrade from the KFHD 8.9
Reviews.Author: Martin Gregorski
Reviews.Content: I upgraded from the KFHD 8.9 and the new HDX doesn't disappoint in any way.  It is better at everything than the "old" HD.The screen on this thing in STUNNING. It has the nicest screen of any electronic device that I own.  The colors are bright and crisp, movies are wonderful on it.I can actually browse the internet on the HDX.  Sure I could have used the KFHD, but the experience was't great.  The HDX makes it so easy, the pages load fast, Silk is pretty good (but I sideloaded Chrome-which I prefer), just an altogether better experience.My wife grabbed the HDX and couldn't believe how light it was.  It is very thin and light.MISC:  No blue haze on reading books like it's little brother has (7" HDX), I sideloaded an earlier Flash version from Adobe which works well, the iCade bluetooth controller works with the HDX.  Downloading movies in the best setting takes up A LOT of memory.  The back camera works well and comes with a bunch of edits that you can do to the pictures (create a MEME, as mustaches, etc)

Reviews.Title: AWESOME TABLET
Reviews.Author: Kesharon
Reviews.Content: Absolutely love it!  If you are an Amazon Prime Member, this is a must have.  The display totally beats the iPad, especially since Apple came out with iOS7 which changed the display on my iPad2 and mini for the worse.  The sound on the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 is awesome.  Streaming is quick, clear and little to no buffering.  The interface is easy to understand and initial screen tips make it very easy to operate out of the box.  Does it have tons of apps? No.  But does it have more than enough features to keep you entertained?  Absolutely!  Here are some of the features my family have used and like:streaming prime movies and shows for freeease of adding an audible option to an existing ebookability to follow along with text to speechadding book marks and notes to the audio versiongetting a digital copy of a book for $.99 after purchase of a physical copyblown away by the picture quality of graphic novelschanging the format of the web browser for better reading viewsThis is for anyone looking for a tablet and loves Amazon!

Reviews.Title: UPDATE: Kindle Fire HDX was NOT what I expected!!!
Reviews.Author: Bennett Jackson
Reviews.Content: I recently ordered the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" and I was very happy with the device, if only for the 4 hours that the Kindle actually worked properly. The Kindle reset on it's own once or twice within a span of twenty minutes, but it eventually loaded after a few minutes. Then the device reset itself after I tried to start up a new app for my e-mail, it took 20 minutes with the Kindle resetting over and over before it came back on. I contacted customer service and I was told that my problem would have to be forwarded to the Kindle developers and I probably wouldn't hear back for a few business days.So far my Kindle is still running through the power cycle, over and over, but if I don't get this issue resolved and receive a new Kindle within the next week I will be demanding a refund.I did enjoy the high-def quality of the screen and how it played videos. I just wish Amazon got rid of all the bugs before putting stock into this new device. I also happened to order the Origami case and I am very happy with this accessory.I really hope this was a fluke and I happened to receive the one Kindle in the whole bunch that didn't work. I'll update my review if I happen to receive a new Kindle.UPDATE:Earlier this week I received a brand new replacement Kindle. Fortunately it seems that the first Kindle Fire HDX that I received just happened to be a, one in a million, defective device. I wanted to wait a few days before I reviewed this item for the second time. I did this so I could see if my new Kindle had the same problems as the old one and I wanted to be able to play with and try to experiment with all the bells and whistles.Display: The display is crisp and clear, with no blue bleeding around the border. This was a problem that some people reported, but that isn't the case with mine.Ease of Use: The Kindle Fire HDX is very simple and easy to use. I have yet to use the Mayday button, but the mere fact that it is there makes all the difference.Apps: There are a lot of apps available for the Kindle and I have downloaded most of the same games and apps that I use on my phone. There are a few apps that are not availble for the Kindle, but they are few and far between.Video: I have used my Amazon Prime membership to watch several free movies and tv shows on the Kindle and I am very impressed with the resolution and playback.Books: I really enjoy using the Kindle to read books. I was dead set against using an e-reader, but my growing hardback and paperback collection and the slowly dwindling space in which to put my books, has made me rethink purchasing a Kindle. I like how the kindle allows me to place bookmarks, toggle text size and most importantly the price of each Kindle version of books I read.The only real issue I had with Amazon, was how long it took them to send me a replacement. All in all, I am thoroughly enjoying my new Kindle and I hope to enjoy it for many years to come.

Reviews.Title: My fourth Kindle is best yet
Reviews.Author: Jean L. Hohnstein "Mugwump"
Reviews.Content: Lovely device! First thing I noticed was the weight -- rather, the "lack of" weight. I hoisted the HDX in one hand and my "old" Kindle Fire HD in the other, and it was the proverbial night-and-day moment. The fact it's slightly smaller and thinner as well is great, but holding it for a long time, say reading in bed, the older one made my arthritic hands carp and grumble every time. This one does not.Although I had specified the "no-offers" option in my order (which is what I got, let me add) all of a sudden last night at around 10:30 PM I suddenly started getting "offers," much to my shock. However, that turned into an enjoyable experience: I got to test, firsthand, the new Mayday button. I spent perhaps five minutes chatting with a friendly girl named Deborah who, once she verified my claim, took over my Kindle and fixed my problem. This, admittedly, was not an earth-shaking concern, but I was very impressed with how easy it was to use this new service as well as its novelty. iPod, eat your heart out!Two small complaints, neither of which impel me to change my rating of the device from five to four stars: a few of the apps I BOUGHT for the Kindle Fire HD apparently will not work on the new one; and I miss the variety of "wallpaper" available on my earlier one, being left with this slightly odd copper and blue whatever-it-is that appears each time the Kindle opens. I would enjoy having the ability to change the wallpaper at will as I do other Android devices, such as my LG cell.Admittedly, I've used it for only a few days. But so far, I am greatly impressed with its quality in all respects. Stunning screen quality, excellent Dolby sound, very quick responses to moving from, say, email to one's current book . . . Like I said, I like this new Kindle, very much.

Reviews.Title: Big improvement over the previous model
Reviews.Author: K. Brown
Reviews.Content: Got the 32GB model without ads with the quarterly payment option (otherwise, don't think I would have sprung for it).  Let's start out with the good: Extremely thin and light weight, awesome screen, easy setup and navigate. Now the not so good: Battery charger included...but it is the slow 5w charger, not the fast 9w powerfast charger (at least that is what the pop-up window indicated when I plugged it into the charger). But on the other hand, I guess charging it up overnight should be enough for a full charge by morning? So far, I am very pleased with the purchase and would highly recommend this device. Glad to see Amazon using an installment program plan...5 stars for that alone, got me off the fence to make a purchase!

Reviews.Title: If you read newspapers on your Kindle, do NOT buy the HDX
Reviews.Author: rsawey
Reviews.Content: First, let me say that I am a big fan of Amazon in general and Kindles in particular.  My new HDX is the 5th Kindle that I have owned, so I have drunk deeply of the Amazon Kool-Aid, and likely won't be leaving the Amazon ecosystem any time soon.However, if you use your Kindle to read newspapers, do NOT buy the HDX.  Why? Because the newspaper reader on this device does NOT have the "Sections" drop-down menu.  I've verified this with the a very cheerful Mayday consultant.  It wasn't just hidden somewhere.  It just was not there.All of my previous Kindles have had this feature, and I've come to rely on it, particularly when I'm reading a large newspaper such as the "NY Times."  Before, if I wanted to go directly to the "Business" section, I could drop down the menu, touch and be there.  Now I have to scroll and scroll and scroll to get there, being very watchful that I do not go past the section header, a header in a smaller and light font.  In what software design universe is this to be considered an improvement?I really hope the software designers fix this.  For now, I'm reading my newspapers on my old original Kindle Fire.

Reviews.Title: Very satisfied and having a lot of fun with the little machine
Reviews.Author: Pia
Reviews.Content: I bought the kindle as a Christmas gift for myself. I tried to be ahead of the big shopping extravaganza after Thanksgiving and was at first a little bummed when I was told that it would take almost 3 weeks to deliver the tablet. But then I received almost every day a new email, letting me know that the delivery was sooner. It was finally scheduled to be shipped on 12/02 but I received it on 11/30. Made me feel good, barely a week after the order.I received the tablet, plugged it in, turned it on and it worked. A few things gave me a bit of a hard time to figure out, there was no written manual. But there is the 'mayday' button on the tablet. And it worked, just as promised. I hit the button I waited may be 10 sec and I talked to somebody who helped me fix my problem.I've borrowed books through my library, sent emails, updated my facebook page, downloaded a few knitting patterns and transferred others from my desktop to the kindle, I have subscribed to the e-version of a magazine, I read my daily newspaper on the kindle, I watch my Netflix shows on it. I have installed and played a few games.I love the ability of the kindle to read books to me (even if I am not using an audiobook). I'm reading my favorite novel and I need to do dishes, so I can let the tablet read to me and do whatever it is I need to do. Also the instant lookup capabilities are wonderful. I'm bilingual German/English, I can have words (from my novel) translated into german or look the term up in a dictionary or even on Wikipedia - just by touching it on the screen.The cameras (front and back) are fun to play with and I managed to get a few pictures from my notoriously camera-shy dog - she didn't even realize that I was taking a pic of her. I have yet to play with the abilities of the machine to accept commands from the distance, haven't yet gotten around to it.I had no problems connecting Bluetooth devices or set it up for my home-wifi network. The machine doesn't lock up, it doesn't crash, the 2 or 3 things I had were my issues of not knowing and they were resolved by the help I received through the almost instant mayday button.The one thing that annoys me a bit (and I guess that's not the kindle but the amazon shopping page) is that I only can look for books by keywords, but not by let's say author and publishing years (or other more specific things). I receive too many results when I'm looking for something specific. But that's really a minor issue.I'm still discovering every day new things to do with the tablet and it is fun.If I had to describe a really positive shopping experience - this would be it.If I had to describe a tablet that does what I want it to do - this is it.Thank you.

Reviews.Title: Buyer beware!
Reviews.Author: Brian C. McCall
Reviews.Content: Update (12/10/13):After replacing the 64 GB model with the 32 GB model I have not experienced any of the previous issues I had. I have used it for several weeks now and everything works as you would expect. I have updated my rating to 2 stars because while the 32 GB model works, it is not what I wanted and the 64 GB model is, as far as I know, still severely flawed and essentially DOA.Previous review:There is a major problem with this model (64 GB, Wi-Fi). I have had 3 of these so far. You read that right, 3. All have exhibited the same problem. I download Prime Instant Videos and can watch them but once I attempt to delete them, the tablet becomes bricked and totally unresponsive. It will not power back on. Amazon customer service has been quick to replace them but clueless as to what the problem actually is. Do not buy this model if you plan on downloading Prime Instant Videos because you will just end up sending it back, bricked.

Reviews.Title: Not what we hoped for
Reviews.Author: Donna J. Krein
Reviews.Content: We purchased the Kindle HDX, our first ever tablet.  The screen flickered and would take you back to home screen when browsing Internet. After 3 May Day calls and still no resolution we requested to return and try another unit. Bad decision, second unit did same thing. Is it the HDX model? Friends have the Kindle Fire and love them. We wanted to love the HDX but they need to debug them before sending them out to folks.  Now in search of a different tablet, not a Kindle, sorry Amazon.

Reviews.Title: Kindle 8.9 hdx is Awesome!
Reviews.Author: gadjetGirl59
Reviews.Content: Amazon keeps improving their product, Kindle 8.9 HDX is a fine piece of hardware.  I received my tablet Thursday and finally have been able to play with it.  First off, this thing is light, very light, one hand light!.  I had the 1st and 2nd gen Kindle fires and this HDX is a delight to hold.  I have a Samsung 8.9 and is about the same size but the HDX still feels lighter.  I will admit to owning the iPad4 and in my opinion the screen looks clearer and sharper.  The hdx's screen is gorgeous, just gorgeous.  Crystal clear, color is just beautiful and looks just as good as my HDTV.I did get the Origami cover but it adds weight so I will probably send it back.The browser is much faster than the last tablet, just breezes through the pages.  And no stuttering when changing to different sites.  The sound is good, maybe not as loud as the hd, but I normally use earbuds anyway.  But even turned up all the way, there is no distortion.  I was able to down load drop box (able to access content), 1Mobile app, Hulu plus (plays fine), and some other favorites. I do find that their are some apps that have not been updated for the hdx but I assume all good things take time. So no worries. :-)I have opened books to read, NO blue or purple tint.  I even used MayDay because I thought I had a problem downloading the update.  The C/S rep was very nice.  I do not know why people are rating this tablet low, this tablet is a keeper!!

Reviews.Title: Light, Fast and Smooth
Reviews.Author: Charlie G
Reviews.Content: I've had the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 for almost a week and find it a joy to use.  My first reaction when taking it out of the box was how light it is!  The next reaction is its thinness and form factor...you have to marvel at the feel of that thin body but it also seems sturdy (I did try to gently flex the body but it didn't flex).  Then I tried out the new power button which is a great improvement over the Kindle Fire HD 8.9...easy to locate (in spite of the fact it is on the back of the left side), in an intuitive location and easy to depress.  When the screen comes alive it is exceptionally sharp, colors are vibrant and even smaller text is easy to read.  After the set-up which was straight forward, I got to test the new faster processor and was pleasantly surprised...FAST and SMOOTH!  At this point I start rapidly going from one app to another app to calendar to email and the HDX stays with me without lag...this is the real deal!  Now to access the internet...very smooth.  Now I decide to stream a movie from my video library and again smooth and no lag, really good sound quality and...yes, that beautiful screen.  Ok, now for playing music from the cloud...I select a song, it starts playing and the words to the song are displayed as the song progresses which falls into the neat factor category.  I then had a question, looked at the built in manual which didn't provide the answer so I tried out Mayday.  Just as advertised I had tech support on the screen within 15 seconds and after a short explanation of my question the tech talked me through the solution...even taking over the screen for a moment to show me something.  Amazon is on to something with this Mayday...you do not have to experience frustration if you bump up against an issue you can't quickly resolve on your own.  The tech support is friendly, empathetic and anxious to solve your issue...and it happens almost instantly.  For non-technical people this is a particularly wonderful benefit of owning an HDX!!  Amazon's competition should be worried about this feature of customer service.I am not yet sure what to make of Amazon's decision to not include an HDMI out which I used on my HD 8.9 and enjoyed a lot.  I have ordered a miracast compatible device for my tv and will see if that provides the same quality of mirroring that I got with an HDMI cable linked between my HD 8.9 and the tv.  More to be revealed.UPDATE ON MIRACAST DEVICE:  I received the Netgear Push2TV miracast device and after hooking it up to the tv (without firmware update) and connecting the Kindle Fire HDX for mirroring mode, the mirroring was excellent!  Movies streamed from my Library on the Amazon cloud to the Kindle Fire mirrored to the tv without any latency.  Everything else including web surfing, display of photos (either on device or on the cloud), music, etc. mirrored flawlessly.  I attempted the firmware update but ultimately had to call Netgear tech support due to very poor instructions that come with that product(I will deal with that in a review of that product).  So, Amazon's decision to not include an HDMI out is justified based on my experience with mirroring.So, my early reaction to the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 is that it is very light, thinnnn and very responsive.

Reviews.Title: Broke after 48 hours
Reviews.Author: Peter R. Forshay
Reviews.Content: My Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" became unresponsive while trying to delete videos.  It then shut itself off and won't turn back on.  Amazon support tried one restart cycle (hold the power button for 20 sec, then press once more to turn on) and gave up.  Of course it is out of stock at the moment, so the replacement won't get here before leaving for Thanksgiving travel, which I specifically ordered it for.  Time for a refund I guess.It also might be worth noting there is no gmail app.  It's not a deal-breaker, but surprised me.UPDATE (Nov 20)Amazon reported more 8.9" HDX in stock shortly after my initial support call.  They are currently rushing me a replacement to get here before I leave for vacation.  I'll update my rating if the replacement works.  One of the support emails I received also indicated they have been able to recreate the issue with deleting Prime videos and are working on a fix, for what it's worth.

Reviews.Title: Hardware is 5 star, lack of play store access continues to kill this great device
Reviews.Author: Illusionofcntrl
Reviews.Content: The HDX hardware is great. It's amazing to me the advancements in 12 months (seems like Moore's law is 4 x's faster with tablet tech) when comparing the HDX against the HD. Not only is the HDX much faster and lighter, it just feels better. Don't get me wrong, I'm a fan of the HD, but the HDX is just much more refined. The HD now feels clunky in my hand (if that makes sense). The HDX is feather light, and well trimmed it fits better than the previous generation. Peformance, it's running a snapdragon 800 quad core processor it's fast. Noticeably faster than the previous generation HD. Graphics are as advertised. The device is top notch from a hardware and look and feel. The 8.9" form factor can't be beat it is the right size for a tablet.The addition of the volume and power button on the back is a step in the right direction. The addition of the rear facing camera another positive (it takes great pics and vids and includes panorama). The custom Android OS Mojito 3.0 is smooth and well thought out.Overall, everything Amazon advertises about the device seems accurate. In my summation  it's flawed in only one way. However, this flaw will keep me from purchasing future Kindle fire devices. I would recommend making sure you are OK with this flawed approach before deciding to purchase. Much like the original Fire, the HD, and now the HDX does not allow access to the Play store. At first that might not seem like a big deal. Amazon has a decent app store with a fair amount of applications to chose from. However, if you like Youtube, Chrome browser, Battlefield 4 Commander, Gmail, and a host of other apps that many folks use daily you won't be able to get them easily. The worst part is that Amazon doesn't even give you the option to have access to the Play store (other tablet manufacturers do - Samsung). I'd be willing to void my warranty, or lose support for my device if they'd just give us the option of having access to the play store.Your options for getting the apps you want on your Kindle HD/HDX? You can side load. Which means getting the .apk from another device and loading it onto the Kindle. Using a couple of programs you can mostly side load fairly easily once you know how. It works but any updates to the application and you will have to complete the process again (if you want the most current version) and application are updated often. Your second options is to load an alternate app store like 1mobile. The risk of this is that you will increase your chance of downloading an app that includes malicious software. This can happen on the play store as well, but it is more likely to occur on alternative app stores.Strongly consider this weakness before purchasing. If I had play store option, I'd give the Kindle Fire HDX 5 stars. Without it, I can only give 3. If you want the applications that everyone uses, you need to look elsewhere because the HDX might have great hardware but without the applications you will be limited. It's a shame that Amazon has taken this approach.

Reviews.Title: Invincible! - Kindle Fire HDX Kills Thrive in Cold Blood
Reviews.Author: Kaio
Reviews.Content: I was an early adopter of the Toshiba Thrive tablet, and after only 2 years, it started getting wonky; (random screen flickers and CPU hiccups.)  So hubby and I decided to splurge and upgrade to the new Kindle Fire HDX.  This is the one and only Kindle Fire review I'll write, because it's the one and only Kindle Fire we plan to use until it bites the dust, which hopefully won't be for awhile.  I'm not just reviewing the HDX for self gratification and vote collecting; I'm writing this because it's finally in my hot little paws, and I genuinely love this tablet.There's an old Native tradition of extinguishing all campfires and going dark, prior to igniting the New Fire.  It's a time for reflection and rebirth, and very much how it felt rebooting our tablet experience; going dark until our new Fire HDX arrived.  So we extinguished our Thrive, offered it up to the Amazon Trade-In gods, and applied the gift card bestowed upon us to our HDX purchase.  Embracing the stillness of our techno-blackout, we postulated the coming spark of a New Fire and reflected on what we really wanted in a tablet.  We're avid Amazon customers, and figured it's time to make the most of it, so we upgraded to Amazon Prime ahead of our eminent Kindle experience.  There always seems to be perks for Kindle users, and we wanted in.  We came to realize that much had changed with tablets these past two years since we had our Thrive, and felt confident in our decision to take the leap with an HDX.  Amazon has a solid reputation for innovation, so when our trusty Thrive stopped being so trustworthy, Kindle Fire HDX was the first, and only, tablet we considered.When the brave delivery warrior pulled his steed up to the curb, my anticipation was palpable; my coveted precious had finally arrived!  I'd visualized this moment for weeks:  my new HDX cradled atop a velour and golden tussled pillow, shrouded by sunbeams and halos, angelic harps crescendo as trumpeters announce the entrance of my coveted new gizmo -- or perhaps it was just in a plain brown shipping box; I can't recall.  My heart was all aflutter, and I was effervescent with excitement, so I might be romanticizing the moment a tad.  Either way, all hail HDX!Is it just me? But whenever I open a new piece of tech, I get all tingly inside; cracking the outer seal, opening the box, getting a waft of that new toy smell -- a blend of fresh circuit boards, and static-free factory environments.  Not a spec of dust to be found as you peel back the protective stickies to reveal that glistening new gizmo. I see why they call it "Fire" because it feels smokin' hot in my grabby little paws.  In some ways, it feels like Amazon actually read my Thrive review and the exhaustive comment section, because I see many wish-list improvements implemented into this new Fire I'm anxious to ignite.> AmazoidAmazon's tablets are hybrid Android OS. Coming off my Thrive with Android ICS, this was the one area I was most concerned about. Would I like Amazon's hybrid; or would I miss my standard Android OS?  When I told a friend we were getting an HDX, she was surprised, "you're both such avid techies, and Kindle Fire seems to be less than a full-fledged tablet."  Our friend wondered if we'd miss having a true Android experience.  We had the same concerns, at first, but then started to wonder, what is a "true" Android experience anyway?  Different menus and a home screen? Pffft!Sure, Amazoid is a bit of an adjustment; it's completely idiot-proof and more closely mimics what little exposure I've had to Apple iOS, with the addition of carousels.  I'm still a bit concerned that Amazon's hybrid will be overly restrictive, compared to my Android experience, but so far, I like it.  Not having access to Google Play Apps may be the biggest adjustment, but I'm confident that I'll figure out an acceptable workaround, or just learn to live without.  Truthfully, I rarely visit Google Play anyway, and don't need access to endless dreck and borderline malware apps.  I already rent and buy all my movies and books here on Amazon, so other than possibly a few specialty apps, Google Play won't be missed.As far as the OS and my "true" experience with it, Android hasn't been around long enough for this to be a huge change for me.  An OS is like a tablecloth -- you need it to dress and protect the table, but hardly notice it once the meal arrives.  In reality, I do far less geek stuff with my tablets than I do with my laptops, so I think I'm good with the lateral OS shift. Even Windows 8 has made the lateral shift to a more homogenized OS experience, (though I far prefer Win 7,) and iOS is literally giving away the latest iteration of their Mac operating system.  So like it or not, the trends are clear: the all-mighty OS isn't the crown jewel it used to be; sure, it matters to share holders, but doesn't add up to much for rest of us.  It's about the gizmo, not the set dressing.  Homogenized operating systems are here to stay, and ultimately, it's a good thing.  And you can bank that future iterations of Android will follow these same trends.I'd say the differences between Amazoid and Android are negligible from a technical perspective; each has its advantages.  The biggest difference comes in the presentation and general user experience.  Fire is activity based, so the standard Android desktop has been streamlined to favor a more inviting and user friendly interface; clearly marked menus, pictorial carousels, all easy to follow and beckoning to be touched and explored.  Fire feels more like a consumer based experience, rather than a technological one.  Sure, Android is simple, but it still felt like I had the ability to do some computing, on some level.  But it also had its share of hiccups.  Whereas, Fire HDX, is a more controlled environment, centered around activities and experiences, yet with the versatility for productivity and business, and enough horsepower to please the nerdiest of geeks (like me, and the Big Bang clan.)  Fire's copy line, "Designed to do it all" pretty much covers it.  And I have to say, I'm quite impressed.> They Listened!The 'Zon actually cracked open the Suggestion Box!  Amazon reviews are a bit like trial by fire (coincidence?) in that, every flaw is magnified, and products live and die by customer commentary. From what I've witnessed in the exhaustive comments in my Thrive review, and read elsewhere about other tabs, Amazon seems to have actually paid attention to what's being said in our complaints and wish lists, and tried to address the most common issues. Fire HDX has clearly built upon it's multi-generation iterations; it's refined, elegant, very well thought out, and precisely executed.  This is the tablet I wanted in the first place. The only thing missing, is a replaceable battery, which would have been cool (hint-hint, Amazon) but likely unachievable given the sleek design.> Second ScreenI got the Thrive primarily for 2 reasons - ports, and a replaceable battery.  Turns out, I didn't use the ports nearly as much as I thought I would; the full size HDMI was just a pain, because I'd rather have wireless.  Enter Fire HDX -- Amazon made the genius move of adding what essentially adds up to wireless HDMI -- wish granted; thanks Amazon!  Second Screen can play movies or content from your Fire, directly on your HDTV, freeing up your tablet's screen to check email, fling some Angry Birds, or just control the video on your HDTV with Fire's play, pause, etc. controls.  Sweet!  I have an HTPC setup, so not sure how meaningful Second Screen will be for me in the long run, but I can't wait to really delve into it!  Definitely a high-end, trend-setting feature; Gold Standard, for sure.> MiracastSimilar but different to Second Screen. This feature wirelessly mirrors your Fire's screen on your HDTV. I liked doing this with my Thrive, but came to hate the HDMI cable tying me down. You haven't really experienced Angry Birds until you play it on a 50" screen! We definitely will be looking for Miracast accessories.  Just a natural addition to my HTPC setup, and sure to be another Gold Standard option others will copy. Yet another indication that Amazon went all out with Fire HDX, and this geek is impressed.> Anorexically ThinOnly, in this case, that's a good thing.  Fire HDX is literally half the thickness of my Thrive, and half the weight too.  I loved the grabby feel of my Thrive, but over time, I admit it was awkward due to the thickness and weight; especially inside the case.  It was like carrying a textbook.  Fire HDX is thin, but doesn't feel like I'm holding a metal tray, or a techno exoskeleton. It's comfortable in the hands and feels solidly built.  And it's svelte silhouette makes it super easy to tuck away and take on the go.> Screen of Tech GodsThe Fire HDX screen is a nerd guru's dream, and anyone possessing the gift of sight will appreciate it's beauty and clarity. Stunningly vibrant, excellent viewing angles, dripping with saturation; I wish my HDTV had pictures this good.  The screen on this HDX is clearly the crown jewel of all it's impressive specs; it's just that good. Words simply don't do it justice.***Hey Amazon*** - How about making a 60" Kindle HDTV with a stunning screen to rival my new HDX?? Goosebuuumps!!> 10.1" vs. 8.9" vs. 7"I thought I might miss my Thrive's 10.1" screen.  Truthfully, I hardly notice the transition to 8.9".  The slightly smaller size helps make HDX lighter, thinner and easier to handle.  Plus the difference in screen quality is so stark, that I could care less that HDX is 1.2" smaller than my old Thrive.  The 7" HDX is just downright cute!  Hubby really loves it because he thinks it'd be easy to slip into his cargo pants pockets and take on the go. He may get one, but for now, we settled on the 8.9", which has proven to be the absolute perfect size.> No Screen Protector RequiredI'm usually a big fan of those military engineered, 'helicopter blade' screen protectors.  However, I have NO plans to dilute or mar the beauty of this gorgeous HDX screen!  Much as I believe in screen protectors, in this instance, I liken it to keeping a posh leather sofa in plastic. This screen is far too nice not to enjoy it as it was meant to be seen. No way, no how, am I covering this beauty with a ten buck screen protector.  Besides, I trust my Origami Case to protect my HDX in style.  If a worthy screen protector presents itself, I might consider it; but for now, it's 'au naturel,' baby.> 16gb vs. 32gb vs. 64gbIf you want to make a budget friendly decision, this is the place to make it. I'm glad Amazon didn't bother making an 8gb tablet; utterly useless.  16gb is decent, but you will definitely have to keep an eye on your storage.  And keep in mind, storage tends to get wonky the closer it gets to full capacity; so be sure to leave yourself some room to spare.  64gb was tempting, especially if I start getting into downloading movies.  But personally, I sprung for the 32gb as it fit my budget and needs best.  I was only using 14gb on my old 32gb Thrive, so I knew 64gb was an indulgence, not a necessity.  And I'm not exactly conservative with what I'll load up on my tablet.  I delete apps I don't use, simply because I no longer want them, not because I need to conserve space.  And I already loaded my HDX with 5gb of Michael Jackson MP3s alone, so I'm not shy about taking advantage of the storage I've got.  Yes, I do own a 5gb waft of Amazon's Cloud storage, but I'm the kinda guy who doesn't want to put their faith in a solid internet connection being available at all times.  Hiccups happen.  I do use the Cloud for some stuff, but local files can be played anywhere, at any time, no hiccups, no data fees. The Cloud is good for storage and convenience, but when it comes to my most important and frequently used files, I want them stored locally for guaranteed access and privacy.*Even Better: Seagate Central 2gb Personal Cloud - access your files from anywhere in the world.  Works great!***Cloud Tip*** - Sure, the cloud is great for storage and convenience, but just don't be surprised when that "breaking news" hits about how these tech companies are reading all your documents and looking at all your "private" files.  It's been happening since the McCarthy era, at least; now with modern tech.  If I can track my own GPS location and activate my tablet or cell phone's cameras remotely, then I expect others to be able to do the same.  As we know, Amazon 'targets' all of us quite effectively, so it's hardly a big shocker to think others can do the same.  I expect no less, and am somewhat ok with it when people I trust are in charge, and not so thrilled when it's the other guys. If you wanna keep something private, then keep it off the Cloud and keep it to yourself.  It's that simple.> Great Dual CamerasHere's another area where Thrive just sucked over time. I didn't mind the lack of a flash at first, but it soon proved to be a real pain.  Conversely, the dual cams on my HDX take excellent quality pictures. The focus is great, and doesn't take long to zero in on the target.  And the dreaded delay most gadgets have after taking a pic is miniscule to nonexistent.  The LED flash is a HUGE Bonus!  I really came to miss that on my Thrive.  The menus and pic galleries are well laid out, and renderings are fast; just a pleasure to work with all around.***Privacy Tip*** - Keep tabs on what your front facing camera is doing!  My Thrive's front cam used to kick in all on its own, and the little LED would come on, alerting me that the camera was active. Either this was a tech glitch, a rogue app, outright nut-job, or Big Brother was watching every once in a while.  I ended up placing a sticker over the lens since I rarely used the front cam anyway, and didn't like the idea of being spied on by Edward Snowden, or the like. Haven't noticed anything like that with HDX, but I got my eye on it.  So, look sharp, people; that front facing camera may not always be your friend.> Wifi vs. 4g vs. TetheringIt all depends on your needs. 4g will have ongoing fees, and arguably, isn't needed with all the WiFi Hotspots popping up.  (Google is literally launching WiFi balloons into the atmosphere!)  Plus, I'm not fond of Verizon or AT&T.;  (More of a Sprint fan, particularly their budget offshoot, Boost Mobile.)  But if your budget is ok with the data fees, and your needs require it, then go for the 4g model. Just be aware, there are alternatives.Personally, WiFi is all I need. And HDX's dual band antenna really does work quite well; connections are great, with excellent range. However, I do occasionally need the convenience of a 4g data connection, but I do it so infrequently, that an outright data plan is just indulgent.  Besides, I already have a cell phone with unlimited data, and don't feel I should have to pay for that feature twice.  My solution?  I just got the LauncherPro App for my cell phone, found the hidden menu that enables tethering without rooting, and voila -- I can tether my HDX to my cheapo LG Marquee Boost Mobile phone wherever I want; all with unlimited data for $40 bucks a month.  (If you're curious on how to do the same, just poke around a little with LauncherPro on your Android phone; you'll figure it out.  Google search is your friend.)  Truthfully, I rarely tethered my Thrive, but I like knowing I have the capability if needed with this new HDX.  It's more cost effective than being saddled with outright 4g, and I'm not stuck choosing between 2 cell companies I don't like much.***Dear Amazon Gods*** - I've been a very good boy this year.  And I need a good pay-as-you go cell phone.  Kindle Mobile please?  If it's as well thought out and constructed as HDX, I'm in! And pretty please - don't price gouge us by charging extra for tethering.  Tablets are just oversized cell phones when it comes to how they process data.  So just let us tether for free, will ya?  Thanks; cookies and milk are on the table. Love, Kaio> Rooting - Don't Do It!I used to be a fan of it, now I'm not. Frankly, you're putting a lot of faith in the people who created the hacks (yes, "rooting" is just a euphemism for "hacking.")  Personally, I'd rather not trust complete strangers to imbed whatever hacks they've created into a tablet I use for banking. I'm just funny that way.  And since I figured out how to tether with my cell phone via the hidden menus, rooting became obsolete in my world.  Plus, the ROMs never offer all that that much really, and certainly not all the hackers claim; like improved battery life. It's more about driving website traffic to the host sites, and entertaining clever ROM gurus, rather than any tangible benefit, IMO.These guys are smart, no doubt about it -- that's what scares me.  I'm not interested in being some tech genius' beta tester, nor do I care to unleash their rogue code into my devices and willingly breach its security.  Chances are, it's all good and harmless ...probably ..maybe.  But for me, the slim benefits hardly merit the lingering doubt.  The few ROMs and hacks I've tried literally needed me to turn off my firewalls and security software just to work with them, because by definition, they are Trojans.  Sorry, but I'm just not that trusting anymore.  So, ixnay on the rooting for me, thanks much. Proceed at your own risk.Having said that, I would consider rooting if I end up hating the more restrictive Amazoid experience, or decide I just can't live without Google Play Apps.  But at this point, I seriously doubt I'll do it.  I just don't trust it.  Plus, I already know how to get the apps I want onto the HDX directly, including Google play, all without rooting, so I'm not worried.***No-Root Tip*** - I'm not going to advise anyone on how to tweak their HDX, so there's no need to ask.  But I will point ya'll in the right direction -- Google "how to side-load apk's" and you'll figure out the rest pretty easily on your own.  If that doesn't work, I'm 100% confident there's another workaround that doesn't require rooting.> Amazon Fresh AppSpeaking of apps, I consider it a privilege to live in an area where Amazon Fresh is available.  Ordering groceries and electronics from my HDX for same day delivery is pretty dreamy; we just LOVE it!  We've been getting grocery delivery, on and off, for years now, so the switch to Amazon Fresh fits our lives perfectly.  The app works great, and we love seeing all the new green trucks humming around town; cannot recommend this service highly enough -- go Amazon Fresh!***Tip - Other Must-Have Apps***-- WiFi Analyzer App - use this to test the WiFi signals around any of your WiFi environments.  Find the best sweet-spots for optimal connections.  If you're super adventurous, get a couple of High Gain Antennas for your router and watch your signal spike!  Just be sure to enable MAC filtering to keep any pesky neighbors from slipstreaming your network.-- Kaspersky One - Antivirus and Internet Security for 5 devices under one low-cost license; any combo of PC, tablets and phones, up to 5 devices.  The app itself can be loaded via a direct link from Kaspersky or the included QR code.-- Team Viewer - remotely control your PC with your tablet while away from home!  Easily transfer files from PC to PC, or even PC to MAC.  Works great. I've tried them all, and this one is still my fave overall. Can't wait to see HDX's iteration of this feature (coming soon!)And now, back to our regularly scheduled programming...> HDX Ergonomic AppealI love the way the volume and power buttons are placed; very natural and comfy to use.  This tablet was clearly designed to be held.  A lot of thought went into form following function, and how this tab naturally rests in my paws.  The weight is distributed well, and it just feels right to hold it; be it 1 or 2 handed.> Additional 2 Year WarrantyThis Verified Purchase would be your clue that I'm not just fishing for votes to up my reviewer rank; I'm a real HDX user, and this is my new day-to-day tablet for the foreseeable future.  I rarely buy extended warranties. I consider tech toys to be somewhat disposable, hence why I traded-in my Thrive as soon as I saw signs of age.  But Fire's extended warranty is actually worthwhile.  It covers accidental damage, and has free replacements shipped out prior to sending the damaged tablet back; replacements are probably refurbs, but still a nice touch.  The warranty also includes battery failure, screen cracks, and zero deductable. For 90 bucks, I'd say that's a good deal, so I sprung for it. Though, given my Thrive started to getting goofy at just 2 years old, I wish this warranty was for 3 years instead.  But I'll take it for the klutz factor, just in case.  (Check my review on the warranty product page if you're interested!)> Origami Case - The Cherry On TopIngenious! A true 'must-have' accessory. Love how it folds to accommodate multiple viewing positions. Love how it turns the HDX on and off automatically.  Love the feel, magnetic fit, and how the camera turns on automatically when you slide the tablet up.  At first, I wanted the polyurethane version, cuz I like the feel and SciFi look.  But I ended up going for the Blue Leather Origami Case because it just seemed classy.  An HDX without this origami case would just be incomplete. I love everything about this case and can't imagine owning the HDX without it.  Perhaps a tad overpriced, but that'll likely drop as HDX settles in.  More colors, please!> Cool SpeakersThe sound from HDX is surprisingly awesome. This is one area Thrive just sucked at, even with the Volume+ app.  But HDX is fantastic.  The custom Dolby really does enhance the fidelity, and I don't feel the need for any audio booster apps.  Naturally, if I wanna shake the house's foundation, I'll be using my home stereo.  But for tiny little speakers, I'd say HDX is as good as it gets. Plus, it's very cool how the origami case reflects the sound. Genius design. Amazon's really just showing off how clever they are with that one.  Kudos!> Where's My Charging Dock?I really liked the convenience of the dock for my Thrive and really thought I'd miss it.  But I'm guessing there will be plenty of goodies and accessories to buy for HDX. The good thing about standardization, like iPad, is that accessories are easier to come by. Same is true for Kindle. But I like the origami case so much, that I really see no need for the dock anymore. So I splurged the extra dough for the case, and have all but forgotten about my old charging dock.> USB Charging PortA universal USB charging port that works with most any standard charger?!?! What the!?  Give that genius a raise and a corner office!  HDX charges faster with the included charger, but nice to know I can use any USB charger handy, wherever I may be.***File Transfer Tip*** - I made a big to-do about wanting the convenience of USB ports to connect my Thrive to my laptops so I could easily transfer and backup files (too bad you couldn't charge via those ports.)  Newsflash - there's a whole bunch of apps out there that help you do direct file transfers to computers wirelessly (Astro File Manager and AirDroid are personal faves.)  Then there's DropBox and Amazon Cloud, so options are plentiful.  I'm a bigger fan of wireless than I am of wired, and have come to realize ports aren't as important as I first thought. Wireless HDMI, wireless file transfers between tablet and PC; Fire HDX is where it's at and I'm good to go!> Battery LifeThe truth of this one will be told over time, but for right now, I'm quite happy with it.  I'd say the 12 hour estimate is pretty close for me, though probably a bit less.  Screen brightness and data intensive apps will hit the battery hardest.  So naturally, I expect my battery life to fluctuate, depending on what I'm doing and how much luminosity I'm dripping from this gorgeous screen.  I just wish the battery was user replicable, but that likely wasn't possible with the ultra-thin body design.  Battery failure is truly is the one area I'm concerned about most; hence why I sprung for the extended warranty.> BluetoothI rarely use it on any of my devices. Just not a fan cuz I think it's one of the top causes of battery drain and OS abnormalities; faulty technology in IMO. But the signal seems fine. My array of stereo headphones sound good, paired smoothly, and stay connected, even from across the room.  But I expect these connections to get choppier outdoors; that's just how bluetooth is.  I predict (fingers crossed) the technology with soon be obsolete, in favor of something more reliable, with less power consumption.***Headset Tip*** - My fave stereo headphones, by far, is the Sony XBA-BT75. Killer sound and rich fidelity for such tiny bluetooth headphones; though nothing beats a thumping subwoofer that shakes the furniture.> Bang For Your BuckFire HDX has many cutting edge features that another nameless tablet would dole out once a year, and expect everyone shell out extra cash for each nominal upgrade. (P.T. Barnum fondly referred to people like this as "suckers.")  HDX is a trend-setting tablet, not a clone or follower.  This is the new Gold Standard, not a money pit.  If you're interested in what a tablet Does in the here and now, then get Fire HDX. If you're interested in owning a status symbol and being accepted by the cool kids, then, that circus is waiting for you.  I already graduated from high school and don't care to revisit that mentality.  Personally, I prefer substance over superficiality; I'm just funny that way.> Business ReadyCompared to HDX, the other Kindle Fires seem like toys. HDX 8.9, specifically, was clearly built for work AND play.  It comes preloaded with my fave OfficeSuite app for Word docs and all that good stuff.  And the specs under the hood are just unmatched.  Miracast and Second Screen would be invaluable in a meeting or presentation. And don't forget TeamViewer for accessing your work computer from anywhere in the world.> Powerhouse IndeedyI've never heard anyone complain that their computer is too fast.  Why buy such a powerhouse tablet? Because everyone, and I mean everyone, wants smooth, snappy and fast tech.  Unless your budget truly does not permit it, don't talk yourself into believing "I don't really need that for what I do."  Remember those words, and live by them, every time your computer or tablet hangs or hiccups.  Don't be the idiot who buys an $80 buck budget tab, and then complains that it doesn't work like iPad.  HDX is the perfect blend of budget and power.  There's just no reason to choose a sub-par gizmo.  The difference in price is nominal, the difference in performance is stark.  The quad core 2gb processor in HDX is an utter beast. It makes my dual core, 1gb Thrive seem like a sloth.  Remote Viewing apps are fast and smooth, as do games, videos, and all processor intensive apps I personally like.> External KeyboardsI'm really not a fan of them for tablets; probably because I hate glitchy bluetooth; invariably, keystrokes are frequently missed.  Besides, I like to touch my tab, even while typing. I do have a keyboard just in case though, and do use it once in awhile. But generally, I just don't see them as necessary for tablets. It just makes things awkward.  I've tried several, and this Logitech Tablet Keyboard is my fave.> MaydayA foolproof brain-fart button that connects you to Amazon Tech Support within 15 seconds. Yup, I tried it, and it works. So glad they couldn't see me in my undies ...I hope -- Eeek!  Another cutting edge, genius feature, sure to become a Gold Standard.> My Little, Preeeecioussssssss....Must have it, I did; love it, I do.  Oh, Kindle HDX; I'm so proud of what you've become. My every dream in a tablet come true; really and truly, that's not just gushing.  Oh ok, it is gushing, but I do mean it.  I just love my tech toys; especially this new HDX!> Accessibility FeaturesKudos, Amazon. As a disabled person myself, I am highly impressed by the screen reader and accessibility options, and your decision to feature them.  But you don't have to be disabled to benefit from them. Tired of squinting at tiny text? Try out one of these great accessibility features, like the screen reader or magnifier.> Read To Me BabyAbsolutely love the Immersive Reading feature and can't wait to really delve into it. Love that Kindle books now have a new way to be enjoyed. I have wanted this feature in a Kindle app since the day I got my Thrive, and so glad that Fire has it; HUGE bonus in my book.> Special Offers or No Special Offers?I debated over this one. It's only a 15 buck difference, and the feature can be turned off at any time by just paying the extra dough.  But I wanted to save a couple bucks, so I opted for the special offers.  Plus, I figure, I'm always shopping at Amazon, so a deal or two once in a while is probably a good thing. However, please keep the ads targeted, Amazon. Please don't start advertizing a bunch of crap to me that my purchase history does not justify. Keep it specific to my needs, and Never, Ever, automatically start playing movie trailers or outright commercials. If I wanna see them, I'll click on it; otherwise, silence is golden.  Last thing I want is my tablet berating me with blatant, noisy advertizing; making a big to-do about something I don't give a crap about. Otherwise, I'll just pay the 15 bucks and dump that feature in a blink.  Do, however, offer me coupons, promotions and deals for stuff you know I'm interested in.  Everyone loves a good coupon!> Holy TrollersYup, it's a real thing, and pretty much what it sounds like; a few highly motivated ones have been stalking me here on Amazon for years, and I'm bored of being 'effed with.  So I took a hiatus from comments a good while ago, and now just focus on trying to write good reviews.  Amazon's new question & answer format integrated into each product's page is a positive step in the right direction, and likely where I'd focus my time if I feel the urge. Perhaps this review will pull me out of my hiatus; so comment away!> Bottom LineThis review is my sizzle to Kindle's Fire; I hope I did this fantastic tab justice.  If you're still reading this, you deserve a prize; I have none for ya, but you deserve one all the same. Perhaps give yourself the prize of a Kindle Fire HDX; and don't forget to nab the Origami case! (Would you believe I even had to shorten this? Looks like I finally found Amazon's review limits.)Yes, I'm one of those nerds who gets excited by tech.  I'm not sure how valuable my skill set is in the real world, but I know gadgets, and HDX gives me goose bumps.  Stunning picture, fast processor and graphics, excellent sound, solidly constructed, superb design, ingenious origami case, and screen readers; plus, Gold Standard features like, Second Screen, Miracast and Mayday tech support -- this tablet is a dream.  Sunbeams, rainbows and angelic harps all over again.In a perfect world, I would have kept my old Thrive forever.  But I'm glad I traded it in while it could still be useful to someone, and was still worth a decent trade-in value to me.  (My gift card from Amazon Trade-In basically got me a free 2 year warranty and origami case for my new HDX.)  I'm thrilled to have made the leap to my new HDX, and absolutely love it!  Now, Amazon, please get busy on that Kindle TV and Kindle Mobile cell phone.  I want your iteration of those toys next! (No doubt they're already in the works.)>>Parting Thoughts<<Haiku of Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 32mb WiFi(*a-hem*).........origami cHictechno-electro-Docious..................maX-azon-azing!Updates likely to follow ...possibly ...maybe ...probably. Meh; whatever.Happy! ;oD*Disclaimer* - The opinions expressed in this review do not necessarily represent anyone whose opinion matters, anyone cares about, or that the author himself remembers typing, though he stands by each and every word vehemently.Time to go play ...HDX style!

Reviews.Title: Sooooo worth the wait!
Reviews.Author: L.L.
Reviews.Content: I really wanted the 8.9 fire last year but it lacked certain features that I really wanted so I purchased the cheapest 7" instead and decided to hold out until the 2013 version of the 8.9 with confidence that Amazon would have it right by then. I'm glad I did!First, delivery time was amazing. I ordered Friday night and to my surprise, it was delivered Saturday afternoon. This was my big gift to myself for this holiday season and I was expecting it to take a couple of weeks to get here like my previous Kindle orders. I'm still waiting on the cover as I decided not to go with the origami case after reading reviews of it being very heavy.As soon as I opened the box and had my precious in my hands, I knew I was right to wait for this version. It's exactly what I wanted. The weight is perfect, the rubber backing and beveling make it easy to hold at any angle.Turning it on with the new button in the back is a breeze. Once it was booted up I was ready to go. All of my apps were waiting to be downloaded from the cloud as well as all of my books and magazines. It took about 10 minutes to download all of them. Some apps aren't available yet for this model, like Draw Something but that's a developer issue, not a Kindle issue. The display is beautiful and crisp and the volume buttons are great. No more swiping down to adjust the volume while watching a video!I've synched two gmail accounts, one for work and one for personal use. I'm able to get notifications for both at the same time which is much easier than logging in and out or having to use two devices to get notifications for each. I've tested Picasso for drawing and the response to the stylus is incredible.I'm loving the side-bar swipe to access other apps while in use of another app instead of having to close out the current app to use another. If I'm watching a video on netflix or reading a book, I can quickly swipe to the side bar, check my email or look something up in wikipedia and then get back to my content.I love the rear camera, which was a big reason for holding out for this version. I've taken a few pictures, edited them on the tablet and shared with facebook from the editor with great ease. Videos are very nice and clear in HD and also very easily uploaded to facebook from the kindle. I would like to see some better video editors in the kindle apps but for now this is good.The processor is super fast, even with several apps open I've had no freeze ups or delays getting to content. Mostly, this is used for entertainment but now and then I need to do some work related stuff while I'm using it for entertainment. No problems at all with pausing a game, retrieving an email with a document, editing the doc, sending out and getting right back to my game.Lastly, battery life. I've been running Swagbucks videos on both the old Kindle Fire and the new one for the last 2.5 hours starting both with a full charge. The old Fire is at 70% now and the new one is at 80%. With the new one I've had it in constant use with games, videos and reading for more than 4 hours at a time without it getting below 56% charge. Including the PowerFast Charger with this Kindle was the cherry on top, it really does charge it fast!I have a lot of faith in Amazon as a company and was certain if I just waited it out another year they would have the tablet I wanted and I was right. Apple quality has been slipping in recent years as they seem more focused on new gimmicks to keep people lined up at their stores every year than quality. I think this tablet will hold it's value for a couple of years at least without feeling like I'm missing out if I don't upgrade it with each new version and that is also important to me. Well done Amazon, you didn't disappoint!

Reviews.Title: Deliciously Light
Reviews.Author: Alfonso Giordano
Reviews.Content: I had an iPad 1 until a friend stole it, never really used it much, never installed many apps, I'm just not an app or game guy.  I prefer using desktop computers (Mac Pro) and real televisions (60" LG 3dtv.)  I have a Kindle 2, Kindle with keyboard, & Kindle Paperwhite for reading (besides tons of real books).  This is the first tablet I'm really using and yes it is for consuming content and buying stuff on Amazon.  It really makes it easy to do so... I'm very so much impressed.  I'll actually watch video on this and the "second screen" functionality works great with my ps3 (that I pretty much only use as a media and blu-ray player.)  I use this tablet everyday, it is as light as light.  I don't care about Google Play or google apps, I'm not using this for productivity or travel.  I would like a VUDU or UV app since I have about a hundred movies on there (Flixster doesn't show them all) otherwise I'm satisfied.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Kindle Fire HDX 8.9"
Reviews.Author: Hattie Belle "Chime"
Reviews.Content: I love the visual qualities, clarity, color; watching videos is a pleasure. I used the live help service once, and it was so satisfying that I felt like a pampered customer. There are other great features and, in addition I am a long-time Amazon fan

Reviews.Title: Better and better!
Reviews.Author: Theodora "OH3"
Reviews.Content: Delighted with this wonderful new Kindle Fire!  Amazingly light and thin, beautiful high def, smooth and fast performance.  The 8.9" size is fantastic.  Rivals iPad in many ways.  Going from the original Kindle Fire to this one is remarkable.  Amazon is making Kindles better and better!

Reviews.Title: It pains me to have to give this one star....
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This is the most difficult one star review I've had to give. Usually a one star product is clearly junk, but that is not the case here.If I were to rate the hardware only (I bought the HDX 8.9 w/o special offers), I would say it's a five star product. But we can't just rate this on hardware alone, we have to look at both the software and Amazon's walled garden policies.I read all the reviews from the gadget sites about how this was somewhat crippled by lack of access to google play, but that you could sideload apps, and that if you wanted to consume Amazon content that it was a good choice. As all I wanted it for was to read ebooks, I thought it would be perfect. It has probably the best screen I've seen on a tablet (compared to my new Galaxy Note 2014 and my wife's Ipad Retina, the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 is the better screen). The problem was I have a lot of technical ebooks (I'm a software developer) from Oreilly press, and I prefer PDF format for these. I also have a few ePub books. I did some research and found moon+ reader pro in the Amazon store. I figured I was good to go, I could buy Moon Reader + pro and have a device that could read all my kindle books, watch amazon prime, and read my ePubs and PDFs. Then the tablet came and I logged in to the store, and Moon Reader + Pro was not listed. I followed a link from the web and lo-and-behold it says "Not compatible with your device"..which was interesting because the free version worked just fine. I wanted the pro because It supports PDFs and the ads are annoying. I then looked for other readers in the Amazon store that would support ePub or PDF and work on my device and guess what...there weren't any. Interestingly enough, there are other readers in the Amazon store such as Aldiko..they just say they aren't compatible with the HDX 8.9.. if you sideload them from the web they work fine though so it's not a compatibility issue. It's Amazon putting artificial limits on what content you can easily view on a kindle device. I don't mind the lack of Google Play because I can understand Amazon not wanting to pay to license from Google or follow Google's policies. But when they have apps that work for what I want in their App store but they intentionally limit access to them to Kindle Devices because they allow ePub and PDF content I have a problem with that.In closing, I would say that if you want to consume Amazon content, an Apple Ipad is currently the best choice. You have full access to a huge selection of apps, and you get the ability to view Amazon Instant Video and you get Text To Speech in the kindle reader. I absolutely despise Apple products so it pains me to recommend them, but for Amazon content the Ipad is the best choice. Android is purposefully crippled by Amazon. They do not have an Instant Video app for Android (other than for the Kindle Fire) and they don't support Text To Speech for Android (again other than the Kindle Fire). As for me I returned the Kindle and bought a Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 2014 edition. I don't get prime videos, but I do get Netflix if I want and I've started looking elsewhere for books and movies.I originally started buying from Amazon because I liked the choice, I liked the customer service, and they made things easy. With this tablet, they have taken away the choice of content and nothing was easy. Customer service is the only thing left. I'll still shop at Amazon for almost everything else I buy, but my great opinion of them was tarnished by the whole experience and I probably won't buy another Kindle device. At least they made it very easy to return the Kindle Fire.

Reviews.Title: A huge improvement over the previous, outstanding version and (please don't hate me) preferred to our iPad5
Reviews.Author: Bob Tobias "Robert Tobias"
Reviews.Content: Quick summary:Pros: - Price - The Mayday feature.  Not for "us", of course.  See the details below for the details. - There are (really useful) apps which you cannot get on an iPad - Price :)Cons: - Not an iPadQuick Bottom Line:  If you want a great, versatile tablet then get this and save some money.  If you need an iPad then get that.Now some details; let's start with a comparison...Size (and weight) (different and may now) matter - This larger version of the Kindle Fire is much smaller, a tiny bit thicker, and a tad lighter than the iPad 5 Air. Of course that means the screen is a bit smaller too, about an inch.  Frankly, from using the previous versions of both  devices, which had similar physical dimensions, everything is close enough to not really matter a lot.Speed - About the same when doing similar activities side-by-side.  Same for wireless down/upload speeds.Available apps.  There are a lot more apps available of the iPad.  Again from personal experience, there are enough of any type available for the Kindle Fire that I can always find one (or more) that I like.  After that, how many note taking apps (for example) do I need?THERE ARE SOME apps available for the Kindle (and android in general) that are not available for the iPad.  One that I use, which for some IS REASON ENOUGH to choose a Kindle, is "WiFi Analyzer".Price - Another tiny difference is that the Fire costs hundreds of dollars less than a similarly configured iPad.  This can matter a lot if none of the other differences do.The May Day Feature - I have friends who bought iPads for their technically challenged, typically older, relativeness.  The intent was to provide a foolproof platform for access to email and those internets.  Sometimes it worked, and sometimes it didn't.
